{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3564562,"name":"Connor","username":"Connor11-6570","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/b782af/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-21T16:21:41.395Z","cooked":"

Hey all, I am a part of team 6570, the
Whiteford Bobcats. We are a team based out of Ottawa Lake, Michigan, and we are preparing for State Competition at SVSU!

As we are preparing, we are trying to get our Robot to follow our paths in Pathplanner correctly and consistently. Our bot listens correctly with short paths going forward and backward, side to side, and even on a small curved path.

We run into a problem with rotating while moving. When we tell our bot to drive straight back and rotate 90 degrees to the right, it does not continue to drive straight while rotating.

This is the path we are telling the robot to follow:

And this is what the robot is actually doing

It’s as if the robot is not taking into account that it has to continue its straight line path. The telemetry in Pathplanner does show the robot following the second path shown, so it knows it is moving incorrectly. We are not sure how to fix this.

The robot is also struggling to be accurate with longer paths

With our long path, we are telling the robot to follow this path:

This is what the robot actually does:

We do have our specifications of that robot in Pathplanner as shown below:

Here is our code:

github.com

GitHub - WHS6570/2025_BubbleGuppies

Contribute to WHS6570/2025_BubbleGuppies development by creating an account on GitHub.

We are open to any possible solutions!

Thank you

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-03-21T16:21:41.395Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":28,"reads":95,"readers_count":94,"score":154.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":496454,"topic_slug":"robot-not-listening-to-path-planner","display_username":"Connor","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/WHS6570/2025_BubbleGuppies","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"GitHub - WHS6570/2025_BubbleGuppies","clicks":8}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56258,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/robot-not-listening-to-path-planner/496454/1","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3564572,"name":"","username":"SnappleBot","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/b3f665/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-21T16:28:56.167Z","cooked":"

what I would do is manually measure on the field each robot position where the robot is lined up with the branch for scoring, then use pathfinding from null(which I believe tells pathplanner to start the path from the current robot position) to those measured branch poses. We ran into a similar issue, where the robot was not reaching the goal end position, and this helped with the issue.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-03-21T16:33:24.802Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":68,"readers_count":67,"score":18.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":496454,"topic_slug":"robot-not-listening-to-path-planner","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":70441,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/robot-not-listening-to-path-planner/496454/2","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3564578,"name":"Connor","username":"Connor11-6570","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/b782af/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-21T16:33:37.081Z","cooked":"

Thank you! We do not physically measure out on the field our specific starting spot. We align the bot in Teleop mode as close to the path as possible then switch over to Auto mode on the driver’s station and run the path. We do use named commands in PathPlanner for auto alignment to the reef for scoring and aligning at the human player station

I would double check what presets or positions your auto align goes to, because sometimes measuring in pathplanner is inaccurate compared to a real field

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-03-21T16:38:31.452Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":58,"readers_count":57,"score":11.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":496454,"topic_slug":"robot-not-listening-to-path-planner","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":56258,"username":"Connor11-6570","name":"Connor","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/b782af/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":70441,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/robot-not-listening-to-path-planner/496454/4","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3564615,"name":"","username":"Luke_Johnson","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/l/67e7ee/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-21T16:54:14.164Z","cooked":"

Your PID values, specifically your P value, seem very low in your AutoBuilder. Usually the default values of (5, 0, 0) are a good starting point for both translation and rotation. Our team has never need to change them beyond that.

Not sure if this will fix your issue, but it could definitely explain why you aren’t reaching your set points correctly, and since your rotational P is even lower, could be why the problem gets noticed during rotation.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-03-21T16:54:14.164Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":56,"readers_count":55,"score":31.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":496454,"topic_slug":"robot-not-listening-to-path-planner","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65764,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4174 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/robot-not-listening-to-path-planner/496454/5","reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3564627,"name":"","username":"SnappleBot","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/b3f665/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-21T17:04:08.297Z","cooked":"

I completely agree! D(in PathPlanner AutoBuilder PID) being changed (even to just 0.1) can completely throw off an entire path, even by just a little bit, but that tiny bit of inaccuracy matters. I would keep I and D at 0 and rotational and translational P at 5.0. I would just copy paste the example code: Getting Started | PathPlanner Docs

We tried to plug in those numbers for our PID and the robot is still doing that second incorrect path just a lot faster now. We tried to tune those numbers but all it changes is how far it drives incorrectly

Make sure your path planner robot config setting are okay. The most important settings to check are wheel radius and true max drive speed.

Building on this, have you done a wheel radius characterization test similar to what 6328 does, or something original? That will help.

We double checked all of our measurements of our bot in PathPlanner and still having the same issue. Another issue we are having is that in telemetry on PathPlanner it shows the bot going the opposite way than what we are telling it. We have not done any radius testing, we have only plugged in our wheel radius. What exactly does 6328 do?

We have tried both ways with robot and field relative to try and fix our issue. We currently have it set to robot relative and it is still not working correctly. The telemetry thinks the bot is going the opposite direction and motors aren’t moving correctly with turning and rotating at the same time

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2025-03-22T19:22:32.947Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":24,"readers_count":23,"score":14.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":496454,"topic_slug":"robot-not-listening-to-path-planner","display_username":"Connor","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56258,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/robot-not-listening-to-path-planner/496454/14","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3565552,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-22T21:55:00.908Z","cooked":"

We haven’t tried this suggested improvement to using the ChassisSpeeds.discretize (not sure if it is included in the CTRE generated code that we use or not - we haven’t had need to look) but maybe it can help you. The “bad” example is the first code block and the improvement is the second code block.

github.com/wpilibsuite/allwpilib

Desaturating `SwerveModuleState[]` after `ChassisSpeeds.discretize` introduces translational drift

opened 09:03PM - 03 Nov 24 UTC
bhall-ctre
type: bug component: wpimath

If you discretize a `ChassisSpeeds`, convert the speeds to module states, and th…en desaturate the module states, translational drift will be introduced to the resulting robot twist. This is how most users currently implement swerve kinematics. > [!NOTE] > Removing the `SwerveDriveKinematics.desaturateWheelSpeeds(states, maxSpeed)` does not fix the problem, it simply creates module states that are not achievable, which introduces other issues (including translational drift). A Java example is shown below: ```java static ChassisSpeeds undiscretize(ChassisSpeeds speeds, double dtSeconds) { // Construct the resulting twist for the timestep var twist = new Twist2d( speeds.vxMetersPerSecond * dtSeconds, speeds.vyMetersPerSecond * dtSeconds, speeds.omegaRadiansPerSecond * dtSeconds ); // Find the desired pose after a timestep, relative to the current pose. var desiredDeltaPose = Pose2d.kZero.exp(twist); // Turn the chassis translation/rotation deltas into average velocities return new ChassisSpeeds( desiredDeltaPose.getX() / dtSeconds, desiredDeltaPose.getY() / dtSeconds, desiredDeltaPose.getRotation().getRadians() / dtSeconds ); } static void testDiscretizeAndDesaturate() { var kinematics = new SwerveDriveKinematics( new Translation2d(0.27, 0.27), new Translation2d(0.27, -0.27), new Translation2d(-0.27, 0.27), new Translation2d(-0.27, -0.27) ); double dt = 0.02; double maxSpeed = 4.0; // impossible chassis speeds, 0 m/s on Y var origSpeeds = new ChassisSpeeds(4, 0, Math.PI * 2.0); // discretize our speeds var speeds = ChassisSpeeds.discretize(origSpeeds, dt); // determine desaturated module states var states = kinematics.toSwerveModuleStates(speeds); SwerveDriveKinematics.desaturateWheelSpeeds(states, maxSpeed); // pull out resulting chassis speeds var desatSpeeds = kinematics.toChassisSpeeds(states); // print effective chassis Y speeds after undoing discretization System.out.println(undiscretize(speeds, dt).vyMetersPerSecond); // -8.67E-17 m/s [GOOD] System.out.println(undiscretize(desatSpeeds, dt).vyMetersPerSecond); // -0.056 m/s [BAD] } ``` If you instead do desaturate -> discretize -> desaturate, the error is reduced significantly (50x in my testing), but is still less than optimal: ```java static void testDesaturateDiscretizeDesaturate() { var kinematics = new SwerveDriveKinematics( new Translation2d(0.27, 0.27), new Translation2d(0.27, -0.27), new Translation2d(-0.27, 0.27), new Translation2d(-0.27, -0.27) ); double dt = 0.02; double maxSpeed = 4.0; // impossible chassis speeds, 0 m/s on Y var origSpeeds = new ChassisSpeeds(4, 0, Math.PI * 2.0); // first desaturate module states with the non-discretized speeds var tmpStates = kinematics.toSwerveModuleStates(origSpeeds); SwerveDriveKinematics.desaturateWheelSpeeds(tmpStates, maxSpeed); // convert back to chassis speeds var speeds = kinematics.toChassisSpeeds(tmpStates); // discretize our speeds speeds = ChassisSpeeds.discretize(speeds, dt); // determine desaturated module states for the discretized speeds var states = kinematics.toSwerveModuleStates(speeds); SwerveDriveKinematics.desaturateWheelSpeeds(states, maxSpeed); // pull out resulting chassis speeds var desatSpeeds = kinematics.toChassisSpeeds(states); // print effective chassis Y speeds after undoing discretization System.out.println(undiscretize(speeds, dt).vyMetersPerSecond); // 3.53E-15 m/s [GOOD] System.out.println(undiscretize(desatSpeeds, dt).vyMetersPerSecond); // -9.1E-4 m/s [OK] } ``` I'm not sure what direction WPILib wants to take to address this issue, but at a minimum it should be documented.
